caption: Figure S1: Ablations on diffusion feature for point tracking at test time, experiments conducted on DAVIS-7 (left) and UCF101-7 (right).
description: The chart is a line graph showing the results of ablation studies on the diffusion feature used for point tracking in a video frame interpolation model.  The x-axis represents the 3D-UNet decoder feature index used for point tracking, indicating different levels of feature abstraction. The y-axis displays two metrics: FID (Fréchet Inception Distance) and FVD (Fréchet Video Distance), both assessing the quality of the generated videos. Two lines are presented, one red for FID and one blue for FVD, each showing how the metric values change across different feature indices. The graph allows to assess the impact of the choice of feature index on the overall performance of the model, indicating which feature level yields the best results in terms of FID and FVD scores.

caption: Figure S1: Ablations on diffusion feature for point tracking at test time, experiments conducted on DAVIS-7 (left) and UCF101-7 (right).
description: The chart displays the impact of using different 3D-UNet decoder feature indices for point tracking on FID and FVD metrics for video interpolation using two datasets, DAVIS-7 and UCF101-7.  The x-axis represents the 3D-UNet decoder feature index utilized for point tracking (0, 1, 2, and 3), and the y-axis displays the FID (red line) and FVD (blue line) scores separately for each dataset.  The chart shows that the optimal FID and FVD scores vary based on the dataset and the index selected, demonstrating that different feature levels within the decoder have differing effects on performance metrics.

caption: Figure S2: Ablations on the start and end diffusion steps for correspondence guidance, experiments conducted on DAVIS-7 (left) and UCF101-7 (right). We use a total sampling step of 30.
description: This chart presents the results of ablation studies on the impact of different ranges of diffusion steps used for correspondence guidance during video frame interpolation.  It shows two lines, one representing the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and the other the Video FID (FVD) scores, both evaluated on the DAVIS-7 dataset. The x-axis displays various ranges of diffusion steps (e.g., 0-6, 0-12, etc.), indicating the start and end points of the guidance. The y-axis represents the FID and FVD scores, respectively. The chart illustrates how different ranges of diffusion steps influence the performance of the model, measured by FID and FVD, allowing for an analysis of which steps are most impactful for achieving good correspondence between frames.

caption: Figure S2: Ablations on the start and end diffusion steps for correspondence guidance, experiments conducted on DAVIS-7 (left) and UCF101-7 (right). We use a total sampling step of 30.
description: This chart displays the results of ablation studies on the impact of different ranges of diffusion steps used for correspondence guidance during video frame interpolation.  It shows the FID and FVD scores for the DAVIS-7 and UCF101-7 datasets, varying the start and end steps of the guidance across several ranges (0-6, 0-12, 0-18, 0-24, 0-30, 6-30, 12-30, 18-30, and 24-30).  The chart uses a line graph with separate lines for FID (red) and FVD (blue) scores for each dataset.  The x-axis represents the range of diffusion steps used for guidance, and the y-axis displays the FID and FVD scores. This visualization helps to assess the relative effectiveness of applying correspondence guidance at different stages of the diffusion process.

caption: Figure S3: Ablations on the number of trajectories for guidance during sampling, experiments conducted on DAVIS-7 (left) and UCF101-7 (right).
description: The chart displays the results of ablation studies on the number of trajectories used for guidance during video frame interpolation.  It presents two lines, one showing the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and the other showing the Fréchet Video Distance (FVD), both calculated on the DAVIS-7 dataset.  The x-axis represents the number of trajectories used for guidance, ranging from 1 to 30. The y-axis shows the FID and FVD scores, with the FID score depicted in red on the left y-axis and the FVD score depicted in blue on the right y-axis.  The chart illustrates how FID and FVD scores change as the number of trajectories increases, showing that using 5 trajectories yields the best performance.

caption: Figure S3: Ablations on the number of trajectories for guidance during sampling, experiments conducted on DAVIS-7 (left) and UCF101-7 (right).
description: The chart displays the impact of varying the number of trajectories used for guidance during the sampling process on FID and FVD scores for both DAVIS-7 and UCF101-7 datasets.  The x-axis represents the number of trajectories (1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 15, 20, 30), and the y-axis shows the corresponding FID (red, left y-axis) and FVD (blue, right y-axis) scores.  The results indicate an optimal number of trajectories exists that minimizes both FID and FVD, showing a relationship between the amount of guidance and the quality of the generated frames.
